metadata.case_name: State Bank of India v. R. K. Jain

facts.text: The first respondent joined the service of the appellant on June 13, 1955 as a Money Tester and was working in that capacity at the Ambala City Branch in July, 1960.

On July 26, 1960, he was deputed to supervise the remittance of unissuable notes of Rs. 87,48,000/- from the Ambala City Branch to the Note Cancellation and Verification Sections of the Reserve Bank of India, Ludhiana for destruction.
Procedure: Currency notes examined, counted, tied in bundles with label containing particulars including initials of examining officer; recounted by Money Tester who initials the label.
Shortage of Rs. 100/- (10 pieces of Rs. 10/- notes) found in packet with label bearing initials of R. K. Jain.
Packet handed back to R. K. Jain; he tore off the label under guise of unstitching, despite protests; torn label kept by RBI officials.
R. K. Jain admitted shortage by letter dated July 29, 1960, stating slip torn inadvertently and repasted after confirming mutilation.
Appellant letter dated August 13, 1960 to R. K. Jain holding him responsible for shortage and tearing label to avoid liability.
R. K. Jain explanation August 16, 1960: Packet handled by several, slip tore accidentally; RBI staff prejudiced due to prior incident where he refused to reimburse Rs. 10/- shortage.
Suspended September 6, 1960 pending inquiry.
Charge sheet October 10, 1960: Shortage in packet recounted by him; tore label to destroy evidence.
Explanation October 18, 1960 by R. K. Jain: Slip tore accidentally due to loose stitching; signed letter drafted by RBI staff; denies deliberate act; alleges prejudice.
First departmental inquiry by B. P. Tiwari commenced December 23, 1960; report February 2, 1961 finding guilty.
During first inquiry, RBI witnesses refused cross-examination; Staff Association protested December 24, 1960.
Respondent examined Pooran Singh and Sanjhi Ram as defense witnesses complaining of RBI staff behavior.
De novo inquiry ordered by B. D. Sharma; notice May 27, 1961 for June 14, 1961.
Staff Association protested second inquiry June 10, 1961 as unfair labour practice.
Second inquiry June 14, 1961 to July 12, 1962; report August 23, 1962 finding guilty.
Request to summon 5 witnesses (including Pooran Singh, Sanjhi Ram) rejected; to produce at own expense.
Show cause notice March 4, 1963 proposing discharge under Sastry Award para 521(10)(c) read with Desai Award 18.28.
Reply March 28, 1963 by R. K. Jain alleging violation of natural justice.
Discharged October 1, 1963 without notice.
Appeal rejected January 18, 1964.
Reference by Central Government September 19, 1966: Whether discharge justified?
Industrial Tribunal award April 7, 1967: Inquiry vitiated, reinstatement with back wages.

legal_issues.text: Whether the domestic inquiries were conducted in accordance with principles of natural justice, particularly regarding opportunity to produce witnesses.
Whether the second inquiry was at the instance of the workman.
Jurisdiction of Tribunal to set aside discharge without finding of mala fides.
Applicability of last part of Sastry Award para 521(10)(c) for discharge where evidence insufficient.
Whether Tribunal should have allowed management to adduce evidence de novo after finding inquiry defective.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal lacked jurisdiction to set aside discharge absent finding of mala fides or victimization.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen; Ananda Bazar Patrika (P) Ltd. v. Its Workmen

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if evidence insufficient, discharge justified under last part of Sastry Award para 521(10)(c).
Duty of workman to produce witnesses; no power in Inquiry Officer to summon; second inquiry at workman's instance.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal erred in not giving opportunity to adduce evidence after finding inquiry defective.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Workmen of Motipur Sugar Factory v. Motipur Sugar Factory; Phulbari Tea Estate v. Its Workmen

respondent_arguments.text: Second inquiry not at workman's instance; protests made by Staff Association.
Violation of natural justice: Refusal to summon witnesses (Pooran Singh, Sanjhi Ram) despite prior expense and management's fault in first inquiry.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sastry Award para 521(9), (10)(a); principles of natural justice

respondent_arguments.text: Management relied solely on domestic inquiry before Tribunal; did not seek to adduce fresh evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Second inquiry not at workman's instance; initiated by management despite protests; first inquiry flawed by RBI witnesses refusing cross-examination.

Violation of natural justice: Unreasonable to expect workman to bear expense again for same witnesses after first inquiry abandoned due to management's fault (RBI witnesses); management bore its witnesses' expenses.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reasonable opportunity to defend provided.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal can interfere if inquiry violates natural justice, even without mala fides.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Inquiry not proper under Sastry Award.

court_reasoning.text: Sastry Award para 521(10)(c) last part inapplicable as inquiry found charges proved, not insufficient evidence.
Management chose to rely solely on domestic inquiry; did not seek or avail opportunity for fresh evidence before Tribunal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No grievance raised in SLP; composite inquiry before Tribunal.

holdings.text: Domestic inquiry vitiated by violation of principles of natural justice; no reasonable opportunity to produce defense witnesses.
Second inquiry conducted at instance of management, not workman.
Tribunal justified in setting aside discharge without requiring fresh evidence as management did not seek it.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Circumstances justifying Tribunal interference: violation of natural justice, mala fides; duty to produce witnesses.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ananda Bazar Patrika (P) Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction of Tribunal; proper domestic inquiry required; refusal of irrelevant witnesses.

precedents_cited.case_name: Workmen of Motipur Sugar Factory Pvt. Ltd. v. Motipur Sugar Factory
precedents_cited.relevance: Management can justify termination before Tribunal if inquiry defective.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Iron & Steel Co. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal jurisdiction where no proper inquiry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Phulbari Tea Estate v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Defective inquiry treated as no inquiry; management to prove facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Its Workman
Bharat Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shri Jai Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal decides on evidence if inquiry defective.

statutes_cited.name: Sastry Award (All India Industrial Tribunal - Bank Disputes)
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for disciplinary action; principles of natural justice; discharge provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Desai Award
statutes_cited.relevance: Read with Sastry Award for discharge without notice.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference for adjudication; approval of action.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; Industrial Tribunal's award upheld setting aside the discharge order as domestic inquiry violated principles of natural justice by denying reasonable opportunity to workman; reinstatement with full back wages directed.

key_quotes.text: If the refusal to examine such a witness, or to allow other evidence to be led appears to be the result of the desire on the part of the enquiry officer to deprive the person charged of an opportunity to establish his innocence, that course, would be a very serious matter.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains limits on refusing witnesses in domestic inquiry.

key_quotes.text: A defective enquiry in our opinion stands on the same footing as no enquiry and in either case the tribunal would have jurisdiction to go into the facts.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Management's right to prove merits before Tribunal.

key_quotes.text: Under those circumstances, in our opinion, the Tribunal was justified in holding that there has been a violation of the principles of natural justice.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on natural justice violation.
